Description: Limestone ostracon: on one side hieratic text in red at the top (two lines), three horizontal lines of hieratic text in black at right angles to the previous. The sketch of a bull was added later. The other side records a list of the ‘personal marks’ of villagers, a kind of signature for people who could not write.
Curator's comments: The ostracon presumably comes from the village of Deir el-Medina, and records a list of villagers for some purpose, now unknown. R.J. Demarée, Ramesside Ostraca (London, 2002), 32, pls. 108-9. For the miscellany text on the recto see H.-W. Fischer-Elfert, 'Lesefunde im literarischen Steinbruch von Deir el-Medineh' ‘Kleine ägyptische Texte’ 12 (Wiesbaden, 1997), pp. 40-43. Cfr. E. Brunner-Traut, 'Die altägyptischen Scherbenbilder’ (Wiesbaden, 1956), p.106, no.109. I. Regulski (ed.), 2022. Hieroglyphs: unlocking ancient Egypt, p. 224 For more on identity marks: B. Haring, 2017. Identity marks in ancient Egypt: scribal and non-scribal modes of visual communication. In Jasink, Anna Margherita, Judith Weingarten, and Silvia Ferrara (eds), Non-scribal communication media in the Bronze Age Aegean and surrounding areas: the semantics of a-literate and proto-literate media, 233-246.
Bibliographic references: Parkinson 1999 / Cracking Codes: The Rosetta Stone and Decipherment (20)
Trismegistos / An interdisciplinary portal of papyrological and epigraphic resources (136374) (http://www.trismegistos.org/text/136374)
Exhibition history: 2015, 19th June - 5th Sept. Wrexham County Borough Museum.
